db:abstract.db:para: A list of all modules in Qt 6.

db:section.db:title: Qt Essentials
db:section.db:para: Qt Essentials define the foundation of Qt on all platforms. They are available on all supported development platforms and on the tested target platforms. Except the testing modules, which will remain source compatible, these modules will remain source and binary compatible throughout Qt 6.

Essential modules are general and useful for a majority of Qt applications. A module that is used for a special purpose is considered an add-on module even if it is available on all supported platforms.
The following table lists the Qt essentials:

db:td.db:para: Core non-graphical classes used by other modules.
Classes for inter-process communication over the D-Bus protocol.
Base classes for graphical user interface (GUI) components.
Classes to make network programming easier and more portable.
Classes for QML and JavaScript languages.
A declarative framework for building highly dynamic applications with custom user interfaces.
Provides lightweight QML types for creating performant user interfaces for desktop, embedded, and mobile devices. These types employ a simple styling architecture and are very efficient.
Layouts are items that are used to arrange Qt Quick 2 based items in the user interface.
A unit test framework for QML applications, where the test cases are written as JavaScript functions.

db:note.db:para: The binary compatibility guarantee does not apply to Qt Quick Test. However, it will remain source compatible.

db:td.db:para: Classes for unit testing Qt applications and libraries.

db:note.db:para: The binary compatibility guarantee does not apply to Qt Test. However, it will remain source compatible.

db:td.db:para: Classes to extend Qt GUI with C++ widgets.

db:section.db:title: Qt Add-Ons
db:section.db:para: Qt Add-On modules bring additional value for specific purposes. These modules may only be available on some development platform. Many add-on modules are either feature-complete and exist for backwards compatibility, or are only applicable to certain platforms. Each add-on module specifies its compatibility promise separately.
The Qt installers include the option of downloading the add-ons. For more information, visit the Getting Started with Qt page.
The following table lists the Qt add-ons:

db:td.db:para: Classes for applications which use ActiveX and COM
Functionality for near-realtime simulation systems with support for 2D and 3D rendering.
Qt Core APIs that were in Qt 5 but not Qt 6.
Classes for writing multi-threaded programs without using low-level threading primitives.
Classes for integrating documentation into applications.
Plugins for additional image formats: TIFF, MNG, TGA, WBMP.
C++ classes that make it easy to use OpenGL in Qt applications. A separate library of Qt OpenGL Widgets C++ Classes provides a widget for rendering OpenGL graphics.
Classes to make printing easier and more portable.
Provides a C++ widget class for displaying a Qt Quick user interface.
Provides classes and tools for creating state machines from SCXML files and embedding them in applications.
Classes for database integration using SQL.
Provides classes for creating and executing state graphs.

Classes for displaying the contents of SVG files. Supports a subset of the SVG 1.2 Tiny standard. A separate library of Qt SVG Widgets C++ Classes provides support for rendering SVG files in a widget UI.
Classes for loading QWidget based forms created in Qt Designer dynamically, at runtime.
Handling of XML in a Document Object Model (DOM) API.

db:th.db:para: Add-ons available under Commercial Licenses, or GNU General Public License v3

db:td.db:para: UI Components for displaying visually pleasing charts, driven by static or dynamic data models.
UI Components for creating stunning 3D data visualizations.
A QML API for rendering graphics and animations in JSON format, exported by the Bodymovin plugin for AdobeÂ® After Effects.
Provides support for OAuth-based authorization to online services.
Linux and Windows desktop, and Boot to Qt targets.
A framework for implementing different input methods as well as a QML virtual keyboard. Supports localized keyboard layouts and custom visual themes.
Provides a high-level API for creating 3D content or UIs based on Qt Quick.
Provides tools for the cross-platform Qt shader pipeline. These enable processing graphics and compute shaders to make them usable for Qt Quick and other components in the Qt ecosystem.
Linux and Boot to Qt targets.
Provides a framework to develop a Wayland compositor.

db:section.db:title: Where to Go from Here
db:section.db:para: We invite you to explore the rest of Qt. We prepared overviews which help you decide which APIs to use and our examples demonstrate how to use our API.

db:listitem.db:para: Qt Overviews - list of topics about application development
Examples and Tutorials - code samples and tutorials
Qt Reference Pages - a listing of C++ and QML APIs
Changes to Supported Modules - status of Qt 5 modules in Qt 6.0
